verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD, saying:
verses.comment: This verse introduces a new prophetic message, consistent with how God speaks through his chosen prophets. Compare with other prophetic introductions, such as Jeremiah 1:2.

verses.text: "Stand in the gate of the LORD's house and proclaim there this word, and say, 'Hear the word of the LORD, all you people of Judah who enter these gates to worship the LORD!'"
verses.comment: God commands Jeremiah to deliver this message at the entrance of the Temple, emphasizing the significance of public worship and the role of the Temple as a central place of encounter with God.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel: "Amend your ways and your deeds, and I will let you dwell in this place."
verses.comment: Repentance is required for God's continued blessing. God desires not only ritual, but also moral reform; see similar calls to conversion in Jeremiah 4:1 and Psalm 15:1.

verses.text: "Do not trust in these deceptive words: 'This is the Temple of the LORD, the Temple of the LORD, the Temple of the LORD.'"
verses.comment: Mere physical presence in God's house is not spiritual security. Jeremiah warns against false assurance, echoed in Micah 3:11 and later by John the Baptist in Matthew 3:9.

verses.text: "For if you truly amend your ways and your deeds, if you truly execute justice between one man and another,"
verses.comment: Justice and righteousness are necessary evidences of authentic faith, see Isaiah 1:17 and Jeremiah 22:3. God's people are called to live out their covenant.

verses.text: "if you do not oppress the foreigner, the fatherless, and the widow, and do not shed innocent blood in this place, nor walk after other gods to your own harm,"
verses.comment: God's concern for the vulnerable is consistent across Scripture. Neglecting justice and turning to other gods brings judgment, see Exodus 22:21-24.

verses.text: "then I will let you dwell in this place, in the land that I gave to your fathers forever and ever."
verses.comment: Obedience secures the promised inheritance. God's faithfulness to the patriarchs sets the foundation for the enduring covenant.

verses.text: "Behold, you trust in deceptive words to no avail."
verses.comment: Empty religious slogans cannot replace true faith and obedience. Jeremiah frequently condemns false prophets and teachers.

verses.text: "Will you steal, murder, commit adultery, swear falsely, burn incense to Baal, and walk after other gods that you have not known,"
verses.comment: The people have broken the commandments, especially the first and most foundational commandments given at Sinai, cf. Exodus 20:13-16.

verses.text: "and then come and stand before Me in this house, which is called by My name, and say, 'We are delivered!'—only to go on doing all these abominations?"
verses.comment: Jeremiah exposes hypocrisy: seeking forgiveness without real repentance. Compare to Isaiah 1:13-15, where God rejects empty ritual.

verses.text: "Has this house, which is called by My name, become a den of robbers in your eyes? Behold, I have seen it, declares the LORD."
verses.comment: Jesus quotes this verse when cleansing the Temple (Matthew 21:13; Mark 11:17). Thus, this passage has a clear christological implication.

verses.text: "But go now to My place that was in Shiloh, where I made My name dwell at first, and see what I did to it because of the wickedness of My people Israel."
verses.comment: Shiloh was once a center for God's presence, yet it fell due to Israel's sin. A history lesson about consequences for disobedience.

verses.text: "And now, because you have done all these works, declares the LORD, and I spoke to you persistently but you did not listen, and I called you but you did not answer,"
verses.comment: God consistently reaches out to His people, showing His patience and desire for their repentance. Persistent calling is a key theme in Jeremiah.

verses.text: "therefore I will do to the house that is called by My name, in which you trust, and to the place that I gave to you and to your fathers, as I did to Shiloh."
verses.comment: God warns that even the Temple is not immune to judgment. The loss of God's presence from Shiloh parallels the warning here.

verses.text: "And I will cast you out of My sight, as I cast out all your kin, all the offspring of Ephraim."
verses.comment: Ephraim (the northern tribes) were already exiled for their sins. Judah receives a similar warning if they persist in rebellion.

verses.text: "As for you, do not pray for this people, nor lift up cry or prayer for them, nor make intercession to Me; for I will not hear you."
verses.comment: There comes a point when intercession is in vain due to hardened hearts; see also Jeremiah 11:14 and 14:11.

verses.text: "Do you not see what they are doing in the cities of Judah and in the streets of Jerusalem?"
verses.comment: Wickedness permeates society. Jeremiah often witnesses and reports the sins of the people.

verses.text: "The children gather wood, the fathers kindle the fire, and the women knead dough, to make cakes to the queen of heaven; and they pour out drink offerings to other gods, to provoke Me to anger."
verses.comment: The entire family is involved in idolatry. The reference to 'queen of heaven' is a condemnation of pagan goddess worship, which persisted into later generations.

verses.text: "Do they provoke Me to anger?" declares the LORD. "Is it not themselves they provoke, to their own shame?"
verses.comment: Sin leads to self-inflicted harm and shame. God's judgment is ultimately a result of people's own actions.

verses.text: "Therefore thus says the Lord GOD: Behold, My anger and My wrath will be poured out on this place, on man and beast, on the trees of the field and the fruit of the ground; it shall burn and not be quenched."
verses.comment: God's judgment affects all creation. This recalls the cosmic effects of sin seen in Isaiah 34:2.

verses.text: Thus says the LORD of Hosts, the God of Israel: "Add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and eat the meat yourselves!"
verses.comment: God rejects empty sacrifices; ritual alone is insufficient. See Isaiah 1:11 and Psalm 50:8-13 for God's attitude toward vain worship.

verses.text: "For in the day that I brought your fathers out of the land of Egypt, I did not speak to them or command them concerning burnt offerings and sacrifices."
verses.comment: God's original call was for obedience, not hollow ritual. Sacrifice came after the covenant call to faithful worship.

verses.text: "But this command I gave them: 'Obey My voice, and I will be your God, and you shall be My people. Walk in all the way that I command you, that it may be well with you.'"
verses.comment: The heart of the covenant is faithful obedience, not outward form. True worship is a response to God’s invitation and command.

verses.text: "But they did not listen or incline their ear, but walked in their own counsels and stubbornness of their evil hearts, and went backward and not forward."
verses.comment: Hardness of heart is a recurring theme in both testaments (see Psalm 81:11-13). True conversion involves turning toward God, not away.

verses.text: "From the day your fathers came out of the land of Egypt to this day, I have persistently sent all My servants the prophets to them, day after day."
verses.comment: God’s persistence in sending prophets signals His mercy and patience. Prophetic tradition is continuous from Exodus onward.

verses.text: "Yet they did not listen to Me or incline their ear, but stiffened their neck; they did worse than their fathers."
verses.comment: Rebellion increases over generations. Failure to heed God’s messengers leads to spiritual decline and greater punishment.

verses.text: "So you shall speak all these words to them, but they will not listen to you. You shall call to them, but they will not answer you."
verses.comment: Jeremiah is to be faithful in proclamation, regardless of response. Prophetic ministry often meets resistance.

verses.text: "And you shall say to them, 'This is the nation that did not obey the voice of the LORD their God and did not accept correction; truth has perished and is cut off from their lips.'"
verses.comment: Loss of truth is evidence of a complete spiritual breakdown. Prophetic voice calls people to accountability and repentance.

verses.text: "Cut off your hair and throw it away, and take up a lamentation on the bare heights, for the LORD has rejected and forsaken the generation of His wrath."
verses.comment: Cutting hair is a sign of mourning and humiliation. Lamentation is a response to God’s rejection due to ongoing sin.

verses.text: "For the people of Judah have done evil in My sight, declares the LORD. They have set their abominations in the house that is called by My name, to defile it."
verses.comment: Similar to Ezekiel’s vision of abominations in the Temple. The desecration of God’s house is a serious matter.

verses.text: "And they have built the high places of Topheth, which is in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, to burn their sons and their daughters in the fire, which I did not command, nor did it enter My mind."
verses.comment: Child sacrifice is utterly abhorrent to God. The Valley of Hinnom later becomes a symbol for the reality of hell (Gehenna) in the New Testament.

verses.text: "Therefore, behold, the days are coming, declares the LORD, when it will no longer be called Topheth or the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, but the Valley of Slaughter; for they will bury in Topheth because there is no room elsewhere."
verses.comment: God’s judgment on the site of their abominations turns it into a place of destruction and lamentation – prophecy fulfilled in Jeremiah 19:6.

verses.text: "And the dead bodies of this people will be food for the birds of the air and for the beasts of the earth, and no one will frighten them away."
verses.comment: God’s curse includes utter desolation, as forewarned in Deuteronomy 28:26 and Jeremiah 16:4. Refers to shame and exposed judgment.

verses.text: "Then I will cause to cease from the cities of Judah and from the streets of Jerusalem the voice of gladness and the voice of joy, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride; for the land shall become a desolation."
verses.comment: Total loss of joy and hope as judgment falls; echoes the spiritual desolation described in Revelation 18:23.
